thread.title: Kansas gets away with travel on game-winner
thread.title_full: Kansas gets away with travel on game-winner

author: Alysha Tsuji, USA TODAY
title: Kansas gets away with travel on game-winner
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Kansas gets away with travel on game-winner WELP. Kansas gets away with travel on game-winner WELP. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2j2YdIv Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted!   Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Kansas gets away with travel on game-winner Alysha Tsuji , USA TODAY 12:08 a.m. ET Jan. 4, 2017 161 Shares 
Kansas Jayhawks guard Sviatoslav Mykhailiuk (10) watches the replay of his final score for the win over the Kansas State Wildcats at Allen Fieldhouse. Kansas won 90 to 88. (Photo: Denny Medley-USA TODAY Sports) 
Kansas State fans have a right to be upset on Tuesday night. 
Kansas' Svi Mykhailiuk managed to get a layup in before the buzzer to get the Jayhawks a win over Kansas State , but, as you may notice in the video of the play, he may have traveled just a bit. Svi coast to coast for the win! pic.twitter.com/ItwAX60l3f — Rob Dauster (@RobDauster) January 4, 2017 
If you're wondering how the heck that wasn't called when the play was reviewed, ESPN's Andy Katz has the answers. This will probably only make Wildcats fans more furious, but here's what Katz's "officiating source" within the Big 12 says : 
Said the source, "That is a judgment call that in fast motion it is very hard to tell if he ended dribble with a foot on floor and went step step or if both feet were in air when ended dribble so it is legal to go step step. Tough play to call either way." 
Additionally, Katz added: They were looking at the clock to make sure he got the shot off on time. They don't go to the monitor for judgment calls. https://t.co/6EblO9amwz — Andy Katz (@ESPNAndyKatz) January 4, 2017 
So yep, Kansas got away with that one. Here is where Svi Mykhailiuk started his final dribble. He's in the backcourt. Only 50 feet away from the bucket. pic.twitter.com/ylItDdZWsN — Jeff Passan (@JeffPassan) January 4, 2017 
Kansas State loses, while Kansas makes the SportsCenter Top 10.
